talk.start.para: e asked the PostmasterGeneral, upon notice -

item.para: What countries in South-East Asia are reached by Radio Australia?
How often each day are the broadcasts given ?
What type of programme is broadcast to this area?
Are there any broadcasts to South-East Asia given in the local language?
If not, is the usefulness of such broadcasts greatly limited?
Is there any co-operation by Radio Australia with the British Broadcasting Corporation's1 Far-Eastern service?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: Radio Australia's transmission are directed to the following countries in South and South-East Asia - Indonesia, Malaya, Thailand, Indo-China, Ceylon, Burma, India and Pakistan, the forces in Korea and Japan, New Caledonia and Tahiti. The Radio Australia coverage also extends to China, Borneo, the Philippines, New Zealand and islands of the North, South and Mid Pacific areas.
The service operates continuously from 9 a.m. Australian eastern time each morning until 3.30 a.m. the following morning.

Programmes are carefully planned to suit the requirements of the different countries in South-East Asia and transmitted to reach each targetarea at optimum listening times. They include bulletins of the latest Australian and world news, talks on Australia by Australian and Asian visitors and commentaries on national and international political and economic development. These are supplemented by especially arranged music session and relays of home service programmes including symphony concerts, variety shows and plays.

Yes. Radio Australia transmits a daily programme of one hour duration in the Indonesian language, and a 45 minute programme daily for French speaking listeners in Indo-China, New Caledonia and Tahiti. Our one-hour programme in Thai is presented each Friday.

Although English is widely used by a large number of educated and influential people in the countries of South-East Asia, nevertheless it is true that the coverage of broadcast. from Radio Australia would be significantly increased with the addition of other Asian language broadcasts.

The British Broadcasting Corporation's far eastern service from London is relayed by the British fur eastern broadcasting service in Singapore. Radio Australia relaysthe British Broadcasting Corporation news to South-East Asia at 4 p.m. Australian eastern time daily, at which time direct, reception from London is unsatisfactory in Singapore. British Broadcasting Corporation news is also relayed each day at 9 p.m.

talk.start.para: e asked the Minister for the Interior, upon notice -

item.para: How are the members of the Australian National Film Board appointed?
Who are the present members?
What were the dates of all meetings of the board since the 1st January, 1052?
Where are copies of colour films produced by the board obtained?
Has the board been satisfied with the quality of its colour copies; if not, what steps have been taken (a) in complaints to the processors, and (b) to obtain copies from some other source?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the Honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: Members of the Australian National Film Board are appointed by the Minister for the Interior.
Messrs. W. A. McLaren (Chairman), S. S. Brown (Deputy Chairman), H. L. White,' T. H. E. Heyes, G. P. Phillips, W. J. Weeden, T.R. M. Sloane, A. J. Baker, N. Edwards, and S. G. Hawes.

1953 - 18th February, 18th March, 21st April, 10th June, 4th August, 16th September, 12th November. At its last meeting the board finally considered a programme that - in addition to urgent work considered likely to arise as a result of requests from Commonwealth departments - it estimated would he sufficient to occupy the Commonwealth film-making units for eighteen months. The board proffered advice to the Minister that this programme should be undertaken and the Minister accepted this advice.

The board is not a producer of films. It is an advisory body to the Minister for the Interior. The producer of Commonwealth films is the Film Division of the News and Information Bureau, Department of the Interior. The Film Division has 16-mm. colour prints of its productions processed by the laboratories of the manufacturers of the film-stock, Kodak (Australasia) Proprietary Limited. This is the only firm undertaking this work in Australia. In the case of 35-mm. Ferraniacolour prints, these are obtained from Denham Laboratories Limited, London. There are no facilities for producing 35-mm. colour prints in Australasia.

No colour copy is ever equal to the original in colour reproduction and variations do occur as a result of the tricky processes of printing and processing. In general, the Film Division is satisfied that the laboratories turn out good copies. Where there have been causes for complaint, the processing laboratories have co-operated to try to improve the quality; sometimes to good effect and always with goodwill. The Film Division does not know of other sources which might provide better service than the makers of the film-stock.

Throughout the motion picture industry it is recognized that, because of the different processes involved, 35-mm. prints, generally speaking, give better screening results than l6-mm. prints, although no exact standards have ever been laid down. This usually applies in the case of Commonwealth productions.
All 16-mm. prints of colour films in circulation are of fair average quality and compare well with the l6-mm. printscirculated by other governments.

talk.start.para: y asked the Treasurer, upon notice -

item.para: What amount of subsidy was paid on butter for the year ended the 30th June, 1954?
What amount is to be paid in the current year?
What would the cost be by way of subsidy in order to reduce the cost of butter to 2s. per lb.?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: The amount of subsidy paid on butter and cheese in 1953-54 was £15,400,000 (approximately). Of this amount, £12,700,000 was paid to reduce the price of these products to Australian consumers and £2,700,000 was paid on exports in accordance with the Government's stabilization plan for the dairying industry.

The amount of subsidy provided in the Estimates for 1954-55 is £15,600,000, comprising £12,700,000 expected to be paid on butter and cheese consumed locally and £2,900,000 on exports under the stabilization plan.

Assuming no change in the level of - domestic consumption and distributors' margins it is estimated that a subsidy of approximately, £44,000,000 per annum would be required to reduce the local retail price of butter to 2s. per lb. and the local retail price of cheese to a comparable figure. The subsidy payable on exports under the stabilization plan would not, of course, be affected.
